Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Great Earthquakes, Megathrust Phenomenology and Continental Dynamics in the Southern Andes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of the project is to understand the processes that created and now drive evolution of the modern Andes. In order to do that, we must understand the spatial and temporal variability of stresses generated in the upper plate by coupling at the plate interface and by viscous drag of the asthenosphere. Specifically, the project will focus on the 2010 Mw 8.8 Maule earthquake in Chile, the earthquake cycle along the Nazca-South America plate interface, orogenesis of the Andean system, and its relationship to crustal deformation and mantle flow.

The project is structured around two main themes:

? How does megathrust phenomenology influence or control the architecture, from forearc to backarc, of the Andean orogeny?
? How do geological materials, shallow structure and slab/mantle dynamics influence or control the behavior and evolution of the megathrust?

The PI group will use GPS and INSAR to examine post-seismic transients and combine these with co-seismic data. They will combine many sources of GPS data (German - GFZ and US groups) that have been collected from 1993 to present over the entire orogen in an effort to develop a synoptic model. This includes data from 33 cGPS stations installed in Chile with NSF-RAPID funds immediately following the Maule earthquake. The regional extent of new analysis will include the rupture zone from the 1960 Mw 9.5 earthquake, which still shows post-seismic transient deformation.

Among the important geodynamic processes that the project will address are (1) time-variable deformation in the aftermath of a great subduction-zone earthquake; (2) improved models of plate interface rheology and their implications for plate boundary earthquake cycles; and (3) interaction between plate boundary and intraplate deformation over time-scales from decadal to geological.

In addition to GPS and InSAR observation of surface deformation, the project brings to bear a number of state-of-the-art observational and modeling approaches; earthquake location and source mechanism determination; geological and geochemical constraints on uplift and erosion rates; inversion for geometric and rheological parameters associated with the plate interface; and large-scale geodynamic modeling. The investigator team is highly qualified to take on these activities, and has a strong track record in previous work in the area. They have developed a strong set of collaborations, both in-country and with other international researchers working in the area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although rare on a human timescale, great earthquakes are globally important processes that are both responses to the accumulation of regional stresses generated by converging tectonic plates, as well as drivers of the complex secondary processes by which these regional stresses are accommodated throughout the collision zone. The transient deformation that occurs in the years following one of these earthquakes provides unique insights into these accommodation processes and allows us infer details of the physical properties of the earth’s crust and mantle in the region affected.

 

The 2010 Mw 8.8 Maule earthquake provided an opportunity to better understand the processes that created and now drive evolution of the modern Andes. The principal objective of our project was to acquire the best geodetic data ever collected for the postseismic transients produced by a great earthquake, and to combine these new data with an excellent (existing) dataset on the coseismic displacements, so to build a comprehensive image of the coseismic and postseismic slip on the plate interface and the response of the southern Andean region to these stresses, with a particular focus on the backarc.

 

We installed more than 30 continuous GPS (CGPS) stations distributed along the rupture zone and from the coastal Chilean forearc to the backarc thrust front in western Argentina. Our analysis of the data collected by this network - and other nearby sites that captured this, and other more recent earthquakes - reveals that the post-seismic deformation evolves with multiple time-scales, ranging from characteristic times on the order of days to weeks, to a decadal-scale component. Importantly, the longer period portions of this signal are detectable much further from the earthquake fault than was generally expected, and extend all the way into the backarc portion of the mountain building zone. This raises the question of what impact, if any, these events might have on backarc structure and processes that were previously thought to be insensitive to activity at the megathrust.

 

Using new and existing GPS data from our South American network we completed a study characterizing the far-field effects of subduction zone earthquakes on the central Andean backarc and subsequently isolated the slow deformation associated with mountain building across the region. We determined that the northern part of the system is more likely to experience wedge-front earthquakes whereas the southern part is more likely to rupture older, internal faults.

 

In order to fully understand the potential impacts of these earthquakes in the backarc, it is important to better understand the structures in this region. We performed numerical modeling of the long-term evolution of mountain belts similar to the eastern flank of the Andes. We found that in our reference models with a homogenous crustal section the new thrust faults that facilitate the growth/widening of the typical back-arc "orogenic wedge" are predicted to form near the surface, rather than growing upwards from the underlying near-horizontal "décollement" fault on which the whole wedge slips. This finding is important for better assessing the seismic hazard in these regions, as it implies that active faults near the wedge-front may be much smaller than previously assumed, and that the likelihood of very large earthquakes associated with these frontal thrust faults might be smaller than thought. These findings aid our understanding of the deformation in fault zones and affects how we assess the impact of stresses generated by the post-seismic viscous deformation of the lower plate on the shallow fault system.

 

The longer-period components of the post-seismic signal are caused by viscous strain in the upper mantle as it adjusts to the sudden stress change caused by the earthquake. Not only does measuring and modeling these signals give us insights into the rheology of the crust and upper mantle, it also helps to refine our models of the fault slip during the earthquake. Our work performing forward and inverse modeling of the rheological structure of the lithosphere to match the post-seismic transients recorded at the GPS sites from megathrust earthquakes continues. Early results distinguish afterslip on the fault from viscous flow of the mantle wedge and suggest that the evolution of stress and strain rate following the Maule earthquake is consistent with a bi-viscous upper mantle rheology with accelerated mantle wedge flow immediately following the earthquake. Elastic thicknesses and asthenospheric viscosities are consistent with estimates from other techniques but initial modeling results generally overestimate near-field displacements and underestimate the far-field signals. Work is ongoing to resolve the source of the model mismatches: both more complex representations of the rheological structure as well as implementing models that include gravity are being explored. Leveraging this work, we are also exploring the impact of rheology and megathrust earthquakes on the transient evolution of the stress field and associated seismicity in the backarc region of the south-central Andes.
